Submissions: https://bristruths.uni-truths.com/
All submissions are fully anonymous. We shall not post anything with student names, initials only please. Nothing crass, derogatory, accusatory or libellous about public figures.
Complaints: If you are unhappy with a post then reporting it just means your beloved page may go down. Message us instead and we shall deal with it ASAP
If you are feeling depressed or suicidal there are people to chat to
https://www.samaritans.org/how-we-can-help-you
www.bigwhitewall.com
http://www.bristol.ac.uk/students/wellbeing/
If there is risk of serious injury or life in danger, call 999
BRISTRUTHS.UNI-TRUTHS.COM
Bristruths

text:
What a year it has been.
We‚Äôve seen our platform grow through war, sharking, and disease, and that was just in Freshers week. Since then we‚Äôve been together through strikes, a global pandemic (and the numerous uni emails that accompanied this), flatcest, rankings of counties and cities that nobody asked for, and the tearing down of the Colston statute. Our admins have been working hard for months to go through the 37,412 submissions we received this year, so : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x42aPmtnVDg. As such, we will be pausing submissions and posts.
Thank you for a lovely year, we shall see you (online or not who knows, certainly not Hugh) in the new term.
The Admins xx
post_text:
What a year it has been.
We‚Äôve seen our platform grow through war, sharking, and disease, and that was just in Freshers week. Since then we‚Äôve been together through strikes, a global pandemic (and the numerous uni emails that accompanied this), flatcest, rankings of counties and cities that nobody asked for, and the tearing down of the Colston statute. Our admins have been working hard for months to go through the 37,412 submissions we received this year, so : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=x42aPmtnVDg. As such, we will be pausing submissions and posts.
Thank you for a lovely year, we shall see you (online or not who knows, certainly not Hugh) in the new term.
The Admins xx

text:
#Bristruth29885
The BLM movement has made me feel really guilty and I'm not sure if that's justified but I thought I should say what I'm feeling. My family were refugees from Iran after the Islamic Revolution and settled in the UK in large numbers. However, they were quite wealthy and all had good educations so weren't really affected too badly apart from being banned from re-entering Iran. One of my distant family had a servant that had come with them from Iran. The two (both female) lived together until around 2008 when they both died. I always felt uncomfortable about this as a child but didn't bring it up until now (having become more conscious about my privelage and wanting to ask questions about this kind of thing). After a few weird answers I did some digging and it turns out that my Iranian family have quite an infamous history and that my actual fucking GRANDAD, my actual grandfather, OWNED AN ETHIOPIAN MAN in the 1950s. Like, not even a servant - an actual fucking slave. IN THE 20TH CENTURY. I actually feel sick and I don't know how to process this because I feel physically ill. Thank God my grandad is dead becuase I don't think I could ever talk to him again. The worst part is that my Iranian mum doesn't think there's anything wrong with this because "it was a different time" and that it was legal where they were. What?! It's literally in living memory! I don't know what happened to the poor man aside that he was a gift from someone in the Iranian government and later ran away. I don't know how to deal with this because I've been the victim of racism in school but now it turns out I'm as bad as white people. My Dad (white) is equally shocked and is unsure about how to feel about this. On the one hand, I know I'm not responsible for the sins of my ancestors but I can't help but feel desperately guilty about this. I'd appreciate any opinions.
post_text:

Please do not use the word ‚Äúparanoid‚Äù to describe how women feel. As a women, many small tasks that men do, such as walking around the city, are daunting. Your reaction by suggesting that not ‚Äúall men are the problem‚Äù is not fixing anything. Of course women know that not all men are bad. (And men claiming women feel this way simply to undermine them are totally incorrect). However, a lot of men are oblivious or don‚Äôt care about the micro aggressions that women face. If you have a look at #bristruth29845, you can see that many women do feel safer due to social distancing. Society should be asking itself why does it take enforcing distance between people to make women feel safe. Moreover, to suggest that women are ‚Äúpretending‚Äù, highlights how ignorant you are. Many men understand and support women, but do so through understanding rather than undermining them. Instead of whining that you are different, why don‚Äôt you speak to your female friends and family about the instances of sexual assault they have faced. Be better.

text:
#Bristruth29882
#Bristruth29872 You know what? I‚Äôd rather be a man and experience my gender being stereotyped as violent/prone to assaulting people, than ACTUALLY get assaulted as a woman. No one is saying ALL men are predators, or assault women, or are dangerous. But enough of a majority are that makes the average woman feel so unsafe that public mandated social distancing allows a welcome break from being harassed in the street. Enough men ARE sexual predators that every single one of my female friends have been assaulted or raped in some from of another, or have at least one horror story to tell of an encounter with men. I think you need to check yourself and realise the bigger issue is that women are constantly faced with danger every day, and rather than crying ‚Äònot all men‚Äô - you need to check your inherent bias, call out people who show this sort of behaviour, and hold your friends accountable when they do this.
P.s: don‚Äôt come here with this whole ‚Äòbut men get assaulted too‚Äô bullshit. Absolutely men get assaulted, and it‚Äôs an awful issue which is often turned into a punchline and isn‚Äôt discussed enough. But if you‚Äôre just bringing up ‚Äòbut men get assaulted too‚Äô ONLY when someone is talking about female assault - then you don‚Äôt actually care about the issue. You‚Äôre just trying to detract from the conversation about female assault, just like when people say ‚Äòall lives matter‚Äô when discussing BLM.

text:
#Bristruth29881
In response to the bristruth about pop and indie music:
All genres of music will seem to lack originality and skill if you only listen to them on a surface level. Indie music is not inherently bad, in the same way you say pop music isn‚Äôt. But if you really want to criticise a genre for having artists that lack talent, you‚Äôre going to sound very silly if you‚Äôve just admitted to being a pop music fan. Maybe try expanding your horizons a little and stop criticising others for their taste in music. People can listen to whatever they want to. This is coming from someone who listens to mostly hiphop, in case anyone thinks I‚Äôm just a butthurt Arctic Monkeys stan.

text:
#Bristruth29871
Bash pop music all you like, it doesn‚Äôt change the fact that the vast majority of pop artists offer something inherently unique, whether it be their voice, style of singing or influence of other genres in their music. The same however can‚Äôt be said for the vast majority of ‚Äòindie‚Äô artists. Ironic considering what indie is supposed to stem from. Listening to an indie playlist comprising many different indie artists is equal to reading a book, where the pace remains constant throughout, there is no character development, climax or any sort of dynamic changes. I‚Äôm not saying there‚Äôs anything wrong with indie music, it‚Äôs just not unique and doesn‚Äôt offer anything fresh or skillful to the world of music - it merely acts as a placeholder for artists who don‚Äôt really know what they‚Äôre doing, can play an instrument and want to desperately pretend that they do know what they‚Äôre doing via an objectively boring and tasteless display of wet, ‚Äòartistic‚Äô twatness. The only reason indie music has such a big stake in the current music climate is because there are a lot of uncultured people out there who base their personalities on what they believe is good instead of using their brain cells to think for themselves.
post_text:
#Bristruth29871
Bash pop music all you like, it doesn‚Äôt change the fact that the vast majority of pop artists offer something inherently unique, whether it be their voice, style of singing or influence of other genres in their music. The same however can‚Äôt be said for the vast majority of ‚Äòindie‚Äô artists. Ironic considering what indie is supposed to stem from. Listening to an indie playlist comprising many different indie artists is equal to reading a book, where the pace remains constant throughout, there is no character development, climax or any sort of dynamic changes. I‚Äôm not saying there‚Äôs anything wrong with indie music, it‚Äôs just not unique and doesn‚Äôt offer anything fresh or skillful to the world of music - it merely acts as a placeholder for artists who don‚Äôt really know what they‚Äôre doing, can play an instrument and want to desperately pretend that they do know what they‚Äôre doing via an objectively boring and tasteless display of wet, ‚Äòartistic‚Äô twatness. The only reason indie music has such a big stake in the current music climate is because there are a lot of uncultured people out there who base their personalities on what they believe is good instead of using their brain cells to think for themselves.

#Bristruth29845
One thing that I'd like to highlight about quarantine / lockdown - as a woman, social distancing has made me feel much safer. I'm not sure if any other women will share this sentiment, but the enforced distance between people has made me feel much safer when it comes to physical sexual assault / unwanted touching. As someone who has been physically sexually assaulted in public by someone unknown to me, a huge weight has been lifted from my mind when it comes to going outside by myself. Where I've previously felt very nervous being outside by myself, passing men in the street or parks, or being near men I dont know due to my previous experience, social distancing has provided me with a physical and mental breathing space from these worries. I'm really interested to see if other people may have felt this way, as its been a really unexpected side effect of lockdown

text:
#Bristruth29843
For those of you who say that anti semitism isn't present at Bristol , let me explain some instances that happened to me over the three years I was there.
1. I was spat on called a '"yid"and told to "return to Israel where I belong"
2. When someone I knew dropped a penny on the floor , one of her friends asked me why I didn't scramble to pick it up as I was jewish.
3. When I said to someone I was minority for being Jewish they replied with " no but you guys don't count because you are white and privelaged"
4. At a party I was told I was " pretty for a Jew" and that they were shocked I " didn't have a big nose or talk like the other North London Jews"
The worst part about people saying these things is that the people around me didn't stick up for me, or even acknowledge what was happening. I'm not saying this stuff to throw anyone under the bus. Jumping down someones throat and calling them a racist doesn't help anyone. They just need to be educated more about said religion / culture/ race. I am saying all this to highlight to everyone how important it is to look after your friends, minority or not.
From an alumni who graduated last year

Well, being that they were all long time friends they clearly already knew he was gay. So in Python fashion, Eric Idle jokingly wrote back claiming they had found Chapman and had him killed.

text:
#Bristruth29833
Ranking of moving out cleaning activities:
#1 (god tier): freezer/fridge - this usually depends on the hygiene situation of the rest of your flatmates but chances are this has never been cleaned since moving in. You‚Äôll find sweet memories of your flatmate‚Äôs ex-partners (and current) who bought crap and left in your fridge months ago, meat of creatures that probably existed in the Mesozoic era given their expiry dates, etc. Things can take a juicy turn if stuff inside have started rotting and the juices start leaking off the food and gets frozen at the bottom - yummy!
#2 (Whoever thats just below god tier): Toilets - people usually expect the shitter to be the grimmest part in here, but take my word they are wrong! Things look fine until you walk into the shower and take a peek into the rarely reached rear ends of the shower caddy. You‚Äôll find shampoo bottles that have been sitting unused for ages but have started leaking, hair blocking the shower drain making the cubicle flood up to your ankle. This latter is usually something that you‚Äôd grown used to as it has been happening pretty much monthly and by now you‚Äôve spent a lot on shower drain cleaners. The culprit is usually someone who shaves his pubes in the shower (or a flatmate‚Äôs girl friend who doesn‚Äôt care cuz it‚Äôs not her place - pretty obvious if you find long hair in an all guys flat). Although you‚Äôve got to be careful as this unknowingly could be you yourself - but if this never happens when you live alone for a while then definitely is not you.
#3: Oven/hobs - this is not far off from the fridge and again depends on the hygiene levels of your flatmates. Imagine bits of chips and god knows what else being baked to perfection repeatedly over a year! Now imagine them being served with fat and a touch of charcoal around the oven door and at all corners of its interior - absolutely amazing!
#4: cupboards - doesn‚Äôt sound like much but wait till you find poorly washed cutlery and bits of food that have been rotting in there for ages. If you are responsible for cleaning these, the trick is to wait for others to leave if possible so you can just throw the stuff away without worrying about them wanting them back.
#5: cleaning own rooms - nobody even cares, it‚Äôs your own shit hole.

#Bristruth29822
I‚Äôm now heading into 3rd year and (assuming uni still goes ahead) I‚Äôm wondering whether it‚Äôs now too late to make any friends at uni? It seems like everyone has formed their set social bubbles and there does seem to be a stigma against those who struggle with social anxiety and making friends. Even though I really like going out and stuff, I have had a hard time making friends at uni and it has been a very lonely couple of years. This lockdown has really reinforced to me that I have no friends and people who keep in touch with me etc, and seeing lockdown being eased and friendship groups meeting up on social media has emphasised this. The prospect of a friendless future does scare me and time seems to be running out. I‚Äôm just wondering what people‚Äôs experiences were and whether people can eventually make uni friends through societies/support groups in 3rd year (and without judgement from people)?

text:
#Bristruth29802
I did a STEM degree in Bristol on a contextual offer, coming from a state school in North England. Graduated first in my year in the end. Contextual offers aren't tokenism; they help people realise their full potential. I didn't have the grades or subject requirements to study my subject at other Russell groups. At the time I struggled to articulate my thoughts or have confidence my ideas so would never have got in if there was an interview. No one was pushing me to do better, or helping me to think about problems in a certain way. That's the kind of thing private school gets you. Now I'm doing a fully funded PhD in Oxford and it's all because Bristol gave me a chance. I don't have a chip on my shoulder about my 'background' because I'm part of the majority in the UK. I just wanted to encourage people to think differently about the reasons for contextual offers and affirmative action in general. Free-market 'meritocracy' will always lead to further inequality until there is true equality of opportunity.

text:
Celebrating Black LGBT+ figures
#BristruthsPride
Over the past month, one thing has been thrust into the public eye following the murder of George Floyd and that is the systemic racism that is built into our society. Protests all over the world are still occurring today and attitudes towards racism are finally starting to shift. It is important though to carry on that fight, to not let politicians and businesses pay lip service and move on as if nothing happened.
That is why Bristruths have created the following document. It highlights the amazing contribution that BAME LGBT+ individuals and QTIPOC have made to the fight for liberation. From the birth of pride with drag queens and ‚Äòtransvestites‚Äô to today's modern heroes who lead the BLM campaign and UK Black Pride. We encourage you to read the document with an open heart and do your own research into the amazing history of gay liberation.
As always, stay safe and remember to look after your mental health during this time. Take a break from social media, check up on your friends and spend time with family. We have also included a list of resources, petitions and sites to consider donating to in order to continue the fight for equality.
In celebration: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1FWahPfg-4kWnXNofbno9AWRD_C6lzN6q/view?usp=sharing
Links:
Black, LGBT+ therapy fund, fuding therapy specific for black, LGBT+ individuals: https://uk.gofundme.com/f/black-lgbtqia-therapy-fund
Exist loudly fund to bring tangible change for black, LGBT+ youth: https://uk.gofundme.com/f/exist-loudly-fund-to-support-queer-black-yp
Free Black Uni, providing decolonised education and producing radical and transformative knowledge: https://uk.gofundme.com/f/the-free-black-university
PRIM.Black for black storytellers and creatives: https://prim.black/
Books to read:
‚ÄúThe Black Flamingo‚Äù by Dean Atta
‚ÄúHow We Fight For Our Lives‚Äù by Saeed Jones
‚ÄúFreshwater‚Äù by Akwaeke Emezi
Nepolanta: An anthology for Queer Poets of Colour (Nightboat Books, 2018)
People to follow:
@TanyaCompas - Twitter & Instagram
@ladyphyll - Instagram (Featured in article)
@kiki_bristol - Black queer collective in Bristol
@_joshrivers - Queer journalist, UK Black Pride head of communications & ‚ÄúBusy Being Black‚Äù podcast host
DRIVE.GOOGLE.COM
In celebration of black LGBT figures.pdf

Great tier: Scotland, 'land' lets it down but otherwise a solid choice, only one where the name of the people is actually in the name of the country so it makes sense, also very fun to say in a Scottish accent. Flag is BORING, would be top great tier if they inverted the colour scheme (I know thats denmark shut up what will they do about it), rename England Britain and leave the union and it's god tier.
Shit Tier: NI, literally identifies itself by the fact it is the north of another country which it isn't even fully north of, no 'official' flag, very poor strategy for branding as all good countries have good flags (observe the bold swedish flag), poor form northern ireland step up your game, your unofficial flag is scary AND I LIKE THAT, make it your official flag and you'll top the list.

How is the sacking of RLB even slightly justified under the narrative of antisemitism? I am very open with this matter, and very willing to have my opinion changed, but for those who havent read what she retweeted, she basically shared an interview of an actress, in which the actress claims the Isreali secret forces train the US police, and that the US police got the knee on the (extremly dangerous and clearly wrong) neck tactic from them. This may or may not be true. Its known that the Isreali forces do infact train US forces, and there are many pictures of the Isreali forces detaining Palestinians in a similar fashion. So my question is, how on earth is what she shared antisemetic? If anything its more antisemetic to equate the isreali govn to Judaism, which is what people are doing when they say what she said was antisemetic, imo. Thanks.

text:
#Bristruth29795
In response to a lot of "defund the police" posts on Instagram: I see your point, but surely taking weapons away from American police will only result in carnage if the population are allowed to bear arms? Defunding police and taking their guns away will surely only heighten gun violence and crime rates. Defunding the police in a heavily-armed country is like asking airlines to take pilots out of planes because 50% of crashes are caused by pilot error - but would you get onto a plane without a pilot? No, because the number of crashes they prevent is greater than those they cause. Similarly, taking the police weaponry away will only increase crime because the police will have no way of stopping people using weapons irresponsibly and committing hate crimes. The best solution is to ban guns altogether, which seems to be working better here in the civilised world.
Defunding the police also does nothing to prevent systemic racism which is what sparked this debate in the first place - why not instead use the funds to educate the police in the damage that their racism has done, which seems more sustainable in the long term?

I'm a Masters student researching student mental health support services for my dissertation, focusing on Bristol as a case study but considering this as a sector-wide issue. If any students with experience of the student mental health support services wish to share their opinions anonymously I would be very grateful. I am looking to gain an understanding of what support services are doing well, what more can be improved and how the changes made over the last few years are working. Please share your experience on this 5-10 minute survey, where all respondents will be anonymous and all information will be treated as confidential. There is an opportunity to share your email in the last question if you wish to participate further. For further information please read the introduction when you click on the survey link or feel free to email me on the email provided in the introduction. Thank you!
https://forms.office.com/Pages/ResponsePage.aspx?id=MEu3vWiVVki9vwZ1l3j8vMT5K4Ebz7ZNr74cICfghftUQkVZQ0o1MUNQSjdNVkVSRDhISEVRTU1QWS4u

text:
#Bristruth29768
I need some help. About a month ago, I had someone move in with me. Since the start of lockdown, I had been living on my own in a 2 bed house. I had been doing okay with living on my own. A little lonely, sure, but I like my own company. It's been a month and this woman is driving me insane. She is super nice, and lovely, but also very messy. Constantly leaving dirty cutlery scattered on the sides, not washing up well enough, going through an unseemly amount of toilet roll, to name a few. And constantly cleaning up after her is really wearing me out, making me feel stressed and like I dont want to be in my own home. I've been thinking of going back home for a week or so to get away from it, but as much as I love my family, we dont get on well for long periods of time. Ive also been spending my free time with my friends when they're free, but I'm starting to feel like a burden on them. I've tried telling her to clean up after herself, but to no avail. Any advice?

It seems like i‚Äôm the only one who is struggling with a bit of PTS after this pandemic. Everyone‚Äôs out here buzzing to go back to clubs, pubs, festivals like Tokyo World and LSTD and on holiday but all of that makes me feel SO unbelievably uncomfortable right now, and I don‚Äôt see myself magically getting over it as soon as July 4th hits. I‚Äôm worried that come September this will really isolate me from my sports society and mates if I still feel this way. I honestly cannot be bothered to have to deal with peer pressure or explain myself if i opt out of going on a night out. It‚Äôs annoying because its my final year and last chance to live like this as a student, but I don‚Äôt think i‚Äôll be mentally ready for it because of the virus.

#Bristruth29759
Im an international black student and I have to say, this university is very cliquey. When it comes to other men especially, from my course to my societies, to my accomodation; all my closer friends are international students since despite making up much less of the uni population, always make an effort to involve me in the group and reciprocate my efforts.
I never made it into the home student friend groups who since freshers would always have plans and meet up and act like they knew each other before uni and already have inside jokes and all. They generally felt impenetrable. So my interactions with home students are more temporary despite my genuine best efforts.
I even realized I still barely know anything about this country and have no friend from here i can even call on.

text:
#Bristruth29756
Heads up UoB, UWE is currently undergoing a review, with one of the outcomes including scrapping Philosophy degrees.
The official statement credits a concern of the programme's "long-term viability" as the largest reason for the review. With the Guardian's 2020 University Guide ranking UWE's philosophy offering highly, at sixth in the whole of the UK, this move comes across as a financially driven decision.
Chris Bertram, the professor in social and political philosophy at Bristol University has already spoken out against it, tweeting: "[This is] a terrible decision that will inevitably reduce access to philosophy for students outside the Russell Group and similar."
Below is the link to the petition, I also suggest emailing lecturers, staff and other UWE representatives.
Link to the petition: https://www.change.org/p/marc-griffiths-uwe-pro-vice-chancellor-and-executive-dean-of-health-and-applied-sciences-save-uwe-s-philosophy-programme

text:
#Bristruth29755
It's a good time to do a privacy check up.
1) Check all of your privacy settings on Facebook, Twitter, IG, etc
2) Move to use a password manager, such as Bitwarden, LastPass, OnePass, etc. And use a unique password per account
3) Enable Two-Factor-Authentication (2FA)
4) Move to a private seach engine like duckduckgo
5) check what information Google knows about you and delete what your not comfortable with
6) Delete any accounts you don't use any more
Stay safe and have a good and private summer! ‚ù§Ô∏è
post_text:

text:
#Bristruth29753
Types of Coffee Drinkers (alphabetically, obviously):
The artisinal: Owns at least 4 different instruments for coffee making, probably has 'a supplier' who hooks them up, judges everyone else's coffee tastes, actually knows the difference between a single and double roast, will only ever go for dates at reputable hipster coffee establishments. Wouldn't be seen dead in a starbucks
The caffeine head: Drinks any brand as long as there's a high amount of caffeine, less than three tablespoons of instant in a morning cup might as well be decafe, is the only person to ever get value for money for the unlimited coffee by going up at least times, occasionally disassociates because of it. Wouldn't be caught dead in a costa, prefers greggs because of their size.
The fake caffeine head: Claims to be a caffeine head but can't handle anything stronger than a teaspoon of instant, complains about 'caffeine withdrawel headaches' after a month of drinking decafe, only ever orders mocha's in cafe's. Wouldn't be caught dead outside of a starbucks, needs a ratio of 100:1 whipped cream:caffeine
The Moderate: Actually normal with their coffee drinking, has one cup in the morning with breakfast after a good nights sleep, doesn't talk about coffee at all, probably owns a machine or caffetiere but doesn't brag about it, most functional of them all, doesn't drink coffee after 10am. Wouldn't be caught dead buying some weird bat poo coffee
The Party animal: Exclusively drinks cold coffee from tesco express after a raging night out, still legally drunk at noon. Looks pretty dead in a 9am.
The Pill popper: Takes caffeine pills for some reason, placebo affect kicks in and they think their dependent after 3 days, doesn't actually drink coffee despite that being infinitely healthier, probably the one person most likely to not actually need the caffeine boost. Would not be caught dead inside a pharmacy actually buying them, always gets them off a friend for free somehow.

text:

ok all of your rankings are boring af so here is one for those merging back into their one direction phase over lockdown
5th place is liam. daddy direction and the basis the group was built on, he‚Äôs a key component to the ORIGINAL five. the start of what makes you beautiful and the start of a phenomenal career but i‚Äôm sorry his solo music is gasp worthy. it‚Äôs alright for the gym but it makes me cringe and is uncomfortable to listen to. ‚ÄúBedroom floor instagram‚Äù says it all.
4th place is niall. controversial to put niall this low don‚Äôt attack me. he has a beautiful soft voice and added an irish charm to the group like no other. i have to put him here because his solo stuff doesn‚Äôt scream fresh. it‚Äôs brilliant don‚Äôt get me wrong but i don‚Äôt find myself DRAWN to it - although his laugh and general meme-ability boosts him in my heart.
3rd place is louis one direction could never have been so successful without this man. he brought the songwriting. we all know that if you like a one direction song it was probably mr tomlinson who wrote it. LOUIS SPARKLED IN NO CONTROL. he‚Äôs cheeky he‚Äôs sassy and was my fave so he goes here :)
2nd place is zayn. he broke our hearts when he left the group to go onto his solo career but you can‚Äôt deny the TALENT. his albums are very vibey and he has the best voice of them all...the high notes and his verses in one direction are unmatched. underrated.
1st OBVIOUSLY harry styles need i say more? star quality. pure talent. a PERFORMER. this man is only going to get bigger. treat people with kindness xxx

#Bristruth29748
I‚Äôm now heading into 3rd year and (assuming uni still goes ahead) I‚Äôm wondering whether it‚Äôs now too late to make any friends at uni? It seems like everyone has formed their set social bubbles and there does seem to be a stigma against those who struggle with social anxiety and making friends. Even though I really like going out and stuff, I have had a hard time making friends at uni and it has been a very lonely couple of years. This lockdown has really reinforced to me that I have no friends and people who keep in touch with me etc, and seeing lockdown being eased and friendship groups meeting up on social media has emphasised this. The prospect of a friendless future does scare me and time seems to be running out. I‚Äôm just wondering what people‚Äôs experiences were and whether people can eventually make uni friends through societies/support groups in 3rd year (and without judgement from people)?

You don't love the pub - you've developed Stockholm syndrome for an addiction to alcohol. You go to the pub because you're not bothered to think of anything else to do. text:
#Bristruth29731
I am sooooo happy I went to a state school and even if I become financially able to send my kids to private school there is no way in hell I would. I believe state school offers you things you're less likely to receive in a private school, such as learning within a class of children from a diverse range of backgrounds, knowing and harnessing how to work hard because no, we don't have tiny class sizes so if you want to get your grades, you put the bloody effort in. Obviously you also work hard at private schools, but from what other posts have said, your academic learning is made easier. But that's not to say I wasn't supported in a state school, I freaking LOVED my teachers, they were truly inspiring and put the effort in to each of their students to get to know them and their needs. A lot of you are apparently upset about the misconceptions of your private schools, but there is also a huge misconception of state schools. Growing up with friends who went to local private schools, I've received comments like "my dad says if I'm bad he'll send me to your school" and "are you scared of leaving things in your locker in case they get stolen?" and to my mum "oh, your daughter got into Bristol, was that because of a lower offer?" Just to point out, I had THE best time in state school and couldn't have asked for a better education, made amazing friends and yes bloody got in to UoB, not through recieving a lower offer, which I did btw, but by exceeding the original offer (and with a free education lads). State school kids, be bloody PROUD, because your education gave you so many more skills than some people seem to believe.

text:
#Bristruth29687
The whole idea of private schools seems so massively unfair to me. I highly doubt that any child pays for themselves to go to a private school with money they have earned. So it is essentially based on what family you are born into and whether they can afford to send you to private school or not, which is something you have no control over at all. These kids get a massive advantage for essentially being lucky.
And the gap between state school and private school kids is only going to grow at the moment: privately educated students are receiving virtual lessons and great communication from their teachers whereas state school students are being sent a few worksheets each week.
I simply can‚Äôt understand how private schools are still accepted in today‚Äôs society, all they seem to do is increase the wealth gap even more, producing young adults who live in their own bubble and cannot fathom the realities of the world we live in. Sorry Allegra/Hugo but your 2 week trip to India/Africa helping impoverished children has not made you ‚Äòwoke‚Äô to the hardships faced by the majority of the planet.
These kids are then flung into top universities doing courses like medicine that require empathy, I struggle to see how they can ever be empathetic when they have never even seen half the hardships their patients will be facing. The ‚Äòwoke‚Äô ones will judge others for for not saving the planet/being vegan/ buying fast fashion/ using plastic with no thought to the fact that sometimes people have no choice but to do these things-beef is a lot more nutritionally dense than lettuce Francesca. They seemingly forget that it‚Äôs their 1% killing the planet the most.
The 1% bubble needs to be popped.

text:
#Bristruth29686
In response to the post about private schools being more advantageous than state schools.
While obviously yes, there is no denying that there are many benefits that come with going to an independent school, the assumption that those that attend are rich and therefore instantly have more opportunities is very misguided. There are multiple scholarships and bursaries awarded for people to be able to access private education. Not only that, but for many parents to send their children to a private school they have to significantly cut back in other areas; they simply value their children‚Äôs education over other things. Be careful about making blanket statements about the type of person someone is or the opportunities they had access to, just because they went to a private institution.

text:
#Bristruth29685
Tagging onto #Bristruth29667 and the one about contextual offers, a big problem where I was from was that I knew people from wealthy families, who could afford tutors etc, who after GCSE's chose to go to schools that got contextual offers purely for that reason. These were people who absolutely had no excuse to get contextual offers, but still did. Worse still, my school didn't have contextual offers (it did have good teachers imo) despite the fact that it basically took in all the pupils from the worst schools in the area, and so pupils I knew who literally went to secondary schools which had principles fired for shall we say naughty behaviour, who had to work second jobs to help their families didn't get contextual offers. I absolutely am glad contextual offers exist (I actually think in some cases they should be more generous with grade reduction), but I seriously think Universities should aim, especially for courses like medicine which need more diversity in that aspect, to be more detailed in checking people's backgrounds.

text:
#BristruthsPride
Pride Begins:
In 1970, on the anniversary of Stonewall, thousands of protestors marched along Greenwich Village which runs past the Stonewall Inn, in what now people have considered the first Gay Pride march. The event, led by Craig Rodwell & Brenda Howard ("The Mother of Pride"), was originally coined as the Christopher Street Liberation Day March. The march, which soon became an annual fixture, was held in order to highlight the community‚Äôs lack of basic civil rights. Many of the people who were involved in organising this protest were the founding members of the Gay Liberation Front (GLF).
Overall, early pride marches were often rarely attended due to fear; and encountered many counter-protests because of the outlandish costumes and colourful floats. However, to the surprise of the organisers, the 1970 New York ‚Äòpride‚Äô march attracted thousands of people. The organisation of the march was a truly monumental task and involved the cooperation of over a dozen LGBT+ rights groups. 2019 Pride marked the 50th anniversary of Stonewall and 2020 marks 50 years of pride since the original march.
Early demonstrations focused primarily on people feeling proud to ‚Äòbe out of the closet‚Äô, on individual freedom and on the diversity of the LGBT+ community. As time went by, more and more cities began to host their own pride marches and they became more and more celebratory ‚Äì eventually evolving into parades rather than marches. However, by the 1980s most major U.S. cities hosted their own events and - particularly due to the spread of AIDS - pride also incorporated socio political activism and many of the marchers carried placards that focused on social issues of the day.
The phrase ‚Äògay pride‚Äô, synonymous with parades in the modern age was thought to be implemented instead of ‚Äògay power‚Äô because ‚Äúpeople did not have power back then, even now, we only have some. But anyone can have pride in themselves, and that would make them happier as people, and produce the movement likely to produce change‚Äù - Craig Schoonmaker; who, alongside Robert A. Martin (AKA - Donny the Punk) & Brenda Howard, coined the term 'gay pride' and were both influential in helping to solidify pride month. Interestingly the reference to 'gay pride' was also supported by Sylvia Rivera, an influential drag queen/‚Äôtransvetite‚Äô and LGBT+ activist.
But why are gay pride parades just that? Why, when they highlight the work still to be done to reach equality, are pride parades more like celebrations and festivals than political marches? The oft-quoted reason for the existence of pride is, indeed, that there is still work to be done. There are still (at the time of writing) 12 countries in the world where gay people can still face capital punishment (execution) simply for being gay. In the U.S. the efforts of LGBT+ rights groups are being reversed by President Trump and all over the world there is a severe lack of equality.
Many people are afraid to come out either due to fear of rejection or danger to their lives if they do. And that is why the jovial and celebratory nature of pride parades can be vitally inspiring. It is also important to contrast the often headline grabbing images of issues that the community face (such as abuse and homelessness) with images of happiness and celebration.
Nowadays, Gay Pride which occurs throughout June is massively popular. Events attract millions, with marches occurring in cities like Amsterdam, Chicago, London, Mexico City, New York, Paris and San Francisco. It was estimated that more than 2 million people celebrated the 2007 Europride event in Madrid. The event, hosted by a different European city each year, was first hosted in London in 1992 and has grown ever since. Madrid also hosted WorldPride, automatically assuming the Europride label, in 2017 ‚Äì the next time the two events will merge is in 2021 in Copenhagen.

Hi guys! To beat the lockdown blues, I've created a form where you can recommend an album, and me and a couple of other volunteers will match you up with a like minded music lover, who will send you an album recommendation in return. Then you and your match, after two weeks of listening, discuss what you think of each other‚Äôs recommendations!
It‚Äôs a way to connect with like-minded people, discover new music that‚Äôs been selected for humans by humans, and give someone else the joy of discovering your favourite album for the first time.
If you'd like to give it a go, please fill in this form https://docs.google.com/forms/d/1smiKg_mfzNtn4J-bHr0R6I2U2AX_CW1XWxCZz7cPNvw/edit?fbclid=IwAR32WmQKTdwmDcw9X6IDKBhriGJMmuD1_f5-BzzuJoa3cQ11XAUvlxAfX-0#response=ACYDBNi0SgCwqQ5lEoaAfO3vvpueHy4s0D1yTRrwtuAjZMB0VQrnVLCv1LGBP0lHrZ_-6Fc . Hoping to get people from all sorts of different unis and demographics participating so give it a go if you like. The form closes for responses this Saturday!

text:
#Bristruth29667
Okay I really do feel I need to write this because some people who go to Bristol clearly don‚Äôt realise the advantage going to a private school provides.
So here‚Äôs a list of advantages most students at private schools have in comparison to students at state schools
1. Smaller class sizes - this enables a teacher to spend far more time per a student.
2. More equipment and resources - many state schools are extremely underfunded which has a massive impact on subjects such as art and computer science.
3. Better links - private schools on average have far more links to companies and people, which enables students to access work experiences opportunities such as in law firms and hospitals that are usually unavailable to an outsider.
4. Personal statement support - private schools give each student far more support and in some cases write areas for their students. This simply doesn‚Äôt happen in state schools, often the only help is via proof reading.
5. Parents who are able to afford remarks and resits. So many people from state schools are simply unable to afford these luxuries.
6. Tutoring- along a similar vein this is far too expensive for many families in state schools.
7. Interview prep for university - this is not something normally offered in many state schools.
8. Extra curricular - again this relates mainly to the fact that those in private schools are, on average wealthy, and can afford to pay for their child to learn instruments or go abroad to volunteer etc.
9. Increased Coursework Help - this is due to a smaller ratio of teachers to pupils.
10. Parental involvement - this is more significant than you many think, having a parent who is proactive in your education and encourages you to work is a huge benefit. Although this obviously occurs in every school, it‚Äôs far more frequent at private schools.
Now many of these things may seem small and insignificant but they really do add up.
I would also like to add that you don‚Äôt automatically get a reduced offer for going to a state school. That‚Äôs just simply untrue.
Contextual offers for schools are given to underperforming/ at risk/ bottom 40% state schools. These tend to be schools which have a v small progression to university.
I would like to point out that there‚Äôs a reason people spend an extortionate amount of money to send their kids to private schools.

text:
#Bristruth29641
On contextual offers: Universities aim to give all applicants equal chances of receiving an offer, even if they may be at a disadvantage compared to other applicants. This is done via positive action, which often takes the form of contextual reduced offers. This is where applicants who are from disadvantaged socio-economic backgrounds are considered for offers at lower grades than the standard offer for a course. Factors considered include the performance of the applicant‚Äôs school or college at GCSE and A Level, as well as the average progress to higher education of the area of the applicant‚Äôs residence. Lower than average figures in either category can increase their chances of receiving a reduced offer. Some universities, such as the University of Birmingham, require multiple conditions to be fulfilled before giving a contextual offer; but others, such as Bristol, only require one in order to be considered for a reduced offer. In the case of the latter, it means that two people in the same year in the same school that they have both attended since Year 7, thus receiving the same quality of education, can receive offers with different grade requirements solely because they live in different areas. Does that really make sense?
Why is this a problem?
Similarly, some universities will give reduced offers to students from state schools solely based on the fact that they attend a state school. When applying for sixth forms, I was told by one (state, non-selective) that I could have a better chance of getting into a top university than if I had continued at my (grammar) secondary school‚Äôs sixth form. I personally don‚Äôt feel that I have had any disadvantage in terms of my education, yet I could‚Äôve been eligible for a lower offer from some universities. On paper, the idea of giving more offers to students from non-selective state schools than private or grammar school students makes sense, but in reality, it fails to take into account a myriad of other factors that would better decide whether a student should receive a reduced offer. They don‚Äôt know anything about the applicant‚Äôs home life or their family‚Äôs background. What if their parents saved up for years just so that their child could receive a better education at a private school? Does the spoilt child from a rich family who went to a comprehensive school deserve consideration for a lower offer, even though they would‚Äôve had just as many opportunities, if not more, to further their education? This is the general issue with a lot of contextual offers: the universities do not have enough information to decide who really does deserve the opportunity to go to university with lower entry requirements. As a result, they have to use the data that they do have, which results in situations like these, where groups of students, whether they are at a disadvantage or not, are all eligible for reduced offers because they tick a box that says they go to a state school, or they live in a certain postcode. The system is fundamentally flawed. This is not necessarily the fault of the university, but a flaw in the application process, which does not provide a sufficient amount of information required to accurately portray the applicant‚Äôs background and circumstances.
It‚Äôs important to note here that I am not suggesting that contextual offers should be abolished entirely. Many reduced offers are given out for perfectly valid reasons, such as missing school time due to illnesses or having special educational needs. I have no issue with these. But sometimes, it does feel like they are given out too generously. Progress is being made, with universities such as Birmingham requiring more than one criteria to be fulfilled, but the only way to properly address the problem is to overhaul the whole system. Individual situations should be considered individually, instead of it being a checklist type system which not only allows reduced offers to be given unnecessarily, but can even prevent some people who should get one from receiving one.

#BristruthPride
Straight people, stop over-sexualising your LGBT friends. I can‚Äôt speak for everyone but I‚Äôve found it‚Äôs not just ‚Äògay jokes‚Äô that make sexuality a punch line, it‚Äôs other comments too. Directing remarks about relationships and sex specifically at gay people that you wouldn‚Äôt at your straight friends is very uncomfortable. It doesn‚Äôt matter if you‚Äôre not someone who tells their friends about hook ups or anything, people can make you feel like this is information you owe them just because you‚Äôve shared something about your sexuality.
To that end, you can identify however you want and you don‚Äôt need to share your credentials to ‚Äòprove it‚Äô, you don‚Äôt even need to have any!
And to the people who slip in these quips or ask weird questions, you‚Äôre showing how unfamiliar you are with having queer friends and that it‚Äôs not normalised in our friendship - I hope it can be.

text:
#Bristruth29634
Here's another rank list for you guys
Strange Things characters ranked from worst to best: (WARNING: CONTAINS SPOILERS)
13. Jonathan Byers ‚Äì While I definitely shipped his and Nancy‚Äôs relationship from the start we must not forget the fact that his hobbies include taking pictures of people without their knowledge ‚Ä¶ creepy. Defo lost some cool points there. Not to mention that after season 1 his character doesn‚Äôt see much development making him one of the more forgettable characters of the season.
12. Nancy Wheeler ‚Äì While she definitely has some pretty badass moments, in general her storyline isn‚Äôt that interesting. Especially in season 3 where they randomly make this character interested in journalism. ???
11. Billy- Ah Billy‚Ä¶If he hadn‚Äôt been a total psychopath until the very last minute, I would have ranked him higher. I must admit Dacre Montgomery‚Äôs acting was superb, how he actually got us to sympathize for a character who literally runs kids over for fun I‚Äôll never know. Also, he‚Äôs hella hot.
10. Will Byers ‚Äì While, yes admittedly the show wouldn‚Äôt exist without him, he didn‚Äôt have much screen time in the first season and I do feel like, no offence, he just doesn‚Äôt have as much personality or flavour as the other characters in the group. Sorry, not sorry.
9. Mike Wheeler‚Äì Him and Eleven are beyond Adorable. However, he can act pretty selfishly at times and get pissed off at people (ahem Max) for literally no reason.
8. Lucas Sinclair ‚Äì He was annoying in season 1 but definitely redeemed himself in later seasons. He‚Äôs a pretty good friend and definitely has his moment of genius at the end of season 3.
7. Jim Hopper ‚Äì Our hero. Hopper is definitely one of the funniest and bravest in the series and I do not lie when I say I balled my eyes out during the letter scene. Unfortunately, he loses points of being an asshole for most of season 3.
6. Max- This girl is as cool as it gets. She‚Äôs badass, she doesn‚Äôt care what people think and she‚Äôs an awesome best friend to Eleven. Actually, if Eleven didn‚Äôt have superpowers Max would probably be cooler than her too.
5. Eleven ‚Äì Everyone in the show would be dead without this girl. Absolute badass.
4. Joyce Byers- Mum GOALS. She‚Äôs kind she‚Äôs caring she always knows what to say and while everyone else always thinks she‚Äôs crazy (magnets anyone?) she doesn't care. In the end, she's always right anyways! Also, her kids ALWAYS come first.
3. Erica Sinclair ‚Äì She‚Äôs sassy and super funny, a natural fit for Steve Dustin and Robin‚Äôs group in season 3. What‚Äôs not to love? HER HIGHLIGHTS: Murray: "I'm sorry, why is this 4-year-old speaking to me?" he asks. ERICA- "I'm 10, you bald bastard"
2. Dustin ‚Äì He‚Äôs funny, energetic and his toothless smile is just downright adorable. His friendship with Steve makes those two the ultimate duo. Not to mention that the singing scene with his girlfriend who turned out to be real, Suzie, was definitely the funniest and most iconic moment of the season.
1. Steve Harrington- MOMMA STEVE. Talk about character development. He went from the person you hope dies in the series to the person you hope never dies. Him adopting the gang is the best thing that happened to the show. I swear, if they kill momma Steve, I WILL delete my Netflix subscription.
Honourable mention ‚Äì
Bob ‚Äì Superhero Bob. I really thought this guy was gonna turn out to be a dick. Proved us wrong. He brings out Joyce‚Äôs nerdier side and is sweeter than a doughnut. Wish he‚Äôd stuck around longer so I could put him on the official list.

text:
#Bristruth29633
My experience as a JCR president was absolute BULLSHIT. As my team and I were the first JCR for our accommodation, we had to start fresh whereas other accommodations such as Orchard Heights and Manor Hall were able to plan events easily and early on. We, however, had no bank account, no access to funding and a very large international community to cater to as well. I was absolutely fuming working one on one with Resilife.. honestly, if you want to call anyone incompetent it's then. They lacked the ability to answer emails, take responsibility for their mistakes, attend meetings, communicate in general and overall just lacked the basic organisation necessary to keep this partnership running smoothly. Our JCR only received access to our money for the year, LAST WEEK. Funnily enough, we've not been in Bristol since March so that doesn't help anyone.
We had so many plans as a JCR to cater to the wishes of the residents but without access to the money and Resilife refusing to pay for events while they held back our money, we were essentially stuck in box. It's as disappointing for a JCR member as it is for a resident to see that money not go towards our plans and not be able to give people what they had asked for. However, what I must say is that if you are going to come for your JCR team without understanding the circumstances that Resilife put them under and also, hello, there's a global pandemic, I'm sorry the government took away your formal that we, as a JCR, worked our asses off for HOURS a week to plan. I was just as pissed off when they cancelled it. But please don't attack your JCRs and call them incompetent when you don't understand the ins and outs of why things happened the way they did. Please remember that we're students with degrees too and we are not going to put our own degrees on hold and at risk for you to sit on a velvet cushion and demand for your wishes to be met.

text:
#Bristruth29631
#brispride my friend from home asked me if I have met many gay people at uni. I told her about the guys I have met but I realised she didn‚Äôt mean guys I had slept with or had flings with. She meant had I met people I could talk about it with in a non-relationship or sexual context. I have realised that although I have met loads of gay guys I have never had a conversation with a lgbt person about my issues or anything personal in Bristol. I feel really awkward about going to a society by myself but I think it would be very beneficial just to talk to people about family or other problems about being gay. I really don‚Äôt know where to go from here.

text:
#Bristruth29611
#Pridemonth. I've known I was bisexual since I was about 14/15 when I realised I was in love with my best friend. Since, I've only ever had serious relationships with guys, and I am more attracted to men generally, but I'm definitely part of the LGBTQ+ community and am still definitely attracted to girls. When I was younger I came out to a few of my friends, but since being at uni I've just not mentioned it. And I don't know if I should feel bad. Should I be acknowledging and celebrating this as part of who I am, or am I okay to keep on just doing my thing? I'm not ashamed of being bi, I just don't know how important it is to share

text:
#Bristruth29516
A note about my own privilege.
First things first, I do not now, nor have ever, considered myself bigoted in anyway. If you'd asked me what I thought about equality when I was 4 or 14 or 24 I'd have given you similar answers, although hopefully advancing a little over that time. The events I'm about to list, the things I've said and done, I did not consider prejudiced at the time. It is only through personal growth and education that I can look back now and see how they were wrong. Almost everyone has been guilty of this at one point or another. Those saying they haven't are either one in a million, lying to themselves because they can't face the truth, or just plainly still bigotted.
I feel that at the moment, with everything that is happening, it is more important than ever to recognise our own (often sub-concious) prejudices and privileges. So here goes. Here are some of the ones I have been guilty of, some of which I've only now recently considered.
"That's so gay" was, for quite some time, the go to insult to use in my experience of primary and early secondary school. I used the word gay as an insult on many occasions. To me, it never meant homosexual. I thought the meaning had changed over time. I was wrong.
This is a privilege I hold through being 'straight'. I've never had to worry about telling my friends and family who I really was. I've never had to hide who I was in love with. I've never had to hide part of myself.
I'm sorry.
I've used sexist insults. I've used certain insults more about women than about men.
This is a privilege I hold through being a man. I've never had to worry about walking through a deserted place late at night. I've never had to think hard about how what I wore would be judged by other people. I've never had to be scared that my voice and ideas would go unheard in a group, simply because of what was between my legs.
I'm sorry.
I've been guilty of not considering my privilege when it comes to race. I've been at a work Christmas do on premises when it was closed to the public. A black man came up and stood outside. I went outside to tell him we were closed. He said "I know" and so I asked what he was doing there. I would have done the exact same to anyone, regardless of race. But I was guilty of not understanding how what I said may come across.
This is a privilege I hold through being white. I've never been asked what I was doing simply because I was standing around. I've never been interrogated by the police for doing absolutely nothing. I've never had to fear for my life simply because of the colour of my skin.
I'm sorry.
I've been guilty of being rude to taxi drivers. I've been in rushes and gotten annoyed when the destination has been misunderstood.
This is a privilige I hold through living in a country thats language is my first. I've never been shouted at to leave the country, simply for the language I was talking in. I've never been attacked for speaking to a friend. I've never been looked down upon for not being born in the country I am in.
I'm sorry.
I've dismissed older peoples views, simply because they were older.
This is a privilege I hold through being young. I've never had to worry about being mocked or patronised or ignored, simply because of my age.
I'm sorry.
I've used ableist language. When I was growing up "that's so gay" was probably on par with "that's so retarded" as the go to insult.
This is a privilige I hold through not being physically or mentally disabled. I've never had to worry about accessing a building that others could freely access. I've never had to worry about not being taken seriously, due to a speech impediment or hearing issue. I've never had to go through being asked to explain a traumatic story of how I became disabled to someone I barely know.
I'm sorry.
I've participated in jokes about all of the above and more. I've told them and laughed at them with friends. Yes, they were jokes. Yes, my friends and I all knew none of us really prescribed to those viewpoints. Yes, I thought that meant it was OK. I was wrong.
This is a privilige I hold through being a young, straight, white, able-bodied, male atheist. I have never been discriminated against based on anything. I have no idea what it's like, or what billions of people go through in this world on a daily basis. And I'm so sorry for my ignorance. I consider myself an ally, above all else. I have for some time now. I have made mistakes. Yes, I was much younger, but this is no excuse.
All we can do is fight to be better. To recognise our priviliges, our prejudices and our mistakes and then fight to create a society where they no longer exist.
Most people in the West hold some form of privilege. Be it from being white, male, straight, not-disabled, young, Christian or atheist. Many people hold multiple privileges as they are members of more than one of these groups. We MUST recognise these.
We must see when they are being taken advantage of, both by ourselves and others, from the past, present and future.
Only then can we begin to drive them away, and truly make the world a fairer, more loving and more beautiful society.

text:
The Catalyst (Part 2/2)
#BristruthsPride
It is widely documented that one of the people who was responsible for the start of this riot was Marsha ‚ÄòPay no mind‚Äô Johnson - like many details reported about Stonewall, this is simply untrue, in fact she said herself that she did not arrive at the bar until the raids had already begun! There are still many claims as to ‚Äòwho threw the first brick‚Äô - many of which not only disagree on WHO threw it, but they disagree on WHAT was even thrown! Regardless, Marsha P. Johnson‚Äôs legacy is still extremely important and she became one of the most vocal activists in the struggle for gay & transgender rights.
Johnson was a black, self described transvestite (transgender was not a widely used term at the time); gay and a drag queen and used she/her pronouns. In an interview in 1989, talking about the riots she said they were a protest against police brutality and harassment against the LGBT+ community - sentiments that are widely echoed today in the BLM campaign.
Following Stonewall, Marsha went on to become a leader in the LGBT+ liberation movement, she was central to the formation of the Gay Liberation Front and, in 1970, she established S.T.A.R - an organisation that was set up with the aim of specifically helping the trans community; a community that was often rejected or left behind by gay rights groups. S.T.A.R then went on to set up a home for homeless LGBT+ youth in New York. In addition to this, Marsha was a huge activist for those that were affected by the HIV/AIDS crisis, despite huge stigma.
Sadly, she suffered from significant mental health problems throughout her life; her body was later found in the Hudson River in 1992, 6 days after she was reported missing. Despite the suspicious circumstances of her death, the police declared it as a suicide and it was never investigated. Many people within the gay community at the time disputed this and the investigation was reopened in 2012. It remains unsolved.
The Stonewall riots symbolised a catalyst for change; they began the gay liberation movement yet also showed an end of a dying conservative or traditionalist era. Before the riots, LGBT+ individuals had never broadcasted their sexual orientation or identity, but the event stimulated the gay community and thus sparked greater political activism.

text:
#Bristruth29489
#Bristruth29416
The university sending an email to show their support for BLM is better than them staying silent. We'd say they were exercising their privilege by not making a stance for the movement. In fact, you saying that it's hypocritical that they're showing support because the university was built off the slave trade can be applied to a lot of people that show their support today. I don't think those people or the university today want to be the benefactors of the slave trade, unfortunately they just are and they're moving in the right direction to do something about it.
And yes, they probably can and should do more, but that's a different argument. I'm just defending people who are at least acting positively for the movement; they shouldn't be attacked, they should be encouraged. A negative attitude won't get people on side as much as a positive attitude will.

text:
#Bristruth29487
In absolute shock at some of the ignorant posts i‚Äôve seen about sympathy for Boris? To feel sympathy for this man is honestly just evidence that you‚Äôve completely neglected the news and choose to be blind to every fatal mistake that he‚Äôs made leaving us with the highest death toll in Europe. Boris missed FIVE cobra meetings about COVID-19. He then put in place a suggested ‚Äòstay at home‚Äô while leaving pubs and clubs open? He raved about shaking hands with COVID-19 patients in one of his daily briefings and did not enforce lockdown until far too late. He DIDN‚ÄôT put in place the fact that people arriving on planes would need to quarantine until May and has literally only just made it necessary to wear face coverings on public transport in June? This is literally only about 1% of his mistakes? Everything people are praising Boris on doing, the rest of Europe has been doing much better? It is honestly painful that you have so much respect for such an awful leader. Do your research. AND ONE MORE THING - saying Dominic Cummings was ‚Äòdoing what any parent would do‚Äô when he drove his child across the country while his wife was suspected of having rona, I expect you all have this same energy when immigrants travel miles to free their children from war torn countries and awful home situations and if not seriously re-evaluate your morals.
Just because your parents tell you Boris is a good leader, take some initiative and do your own research and read the news it‚Äôs literally clear as day he is Dominic Cummings puppet master and just a terrible leader.

Boris missed FIVE cobra meetings about COVID-19. He then put in place a suggested ‚Äòstay at home‚Äô while leaving pubs and clubs open? He raved about shaking hands with COVID-19 patients in one of his daily briefings and did not enforce lockdown until far too late. He DIDN‚ÄôT put in place the fact that people arriving on planes would need to quarantine until May and has literally only just made it necessary to wear face coverings on public transport in June? This is literally only about 1% of his mistakes? Everything people are praising Boris on doing, the rest of Europe has been doing much better? It is honestly painful that you have so much respect for such an awful leader. Do your research. AND ONE MORE THING - saying Dominic Cummings was ‚Äòdoing what any parent would do‚Äô when he drove his child across the country while his wife was suspected of having rona, I expect you all have this same energy when immigrants travel miles to free their children from war torn countries and awful home situations and if not seriously re-evaluate your morals.
Just because your parents tell you Boris is a good leader, take some initiative and do your own research and read the news it‚Äôs literally clear as day he is Dominic Cummings puppet master and just a terrible leader.

We hope everyone is having a good pride month so far and exams are going well. For those of us who are in our final year of university, we‚Äôre coming up to a bittersweet time. Many of us should be celebrating with friends and spending way too much time in Lounge‚Ä¶ Unfortunately this year, that is not the case. So, Bristruths is stepping in to help!
On Sunday 21st June Bristruths will be holding an online graduation for everyone graduating this year. The ceremony will take place on our Minecraft server, but will also be live streamed on the Bristruths page. Everyone graduating this year can take part (you don‚Äôt have to have Minecraft) and even if you‚Äôre not graduating there will be an opportunity to get involved!
After the ceremony, we will also have a quiz that everyone, including those not graduating, can take part in - prizes TBA. To end the day we will of course be heading to Lounge!
If you‚Äôre graduating this year, click going to the event, fill in the form below, and clear your calendar on the 21st!
https://forms.gle/EidPHP3u81FJhoST8
The Admins xxx

text:
#Bristruth29420
Whilst I'm loving the increased awareness of people in the UK for BLM and other movements currently in the US. Sharing a black square is about the laziest way of showing solidarity, and is actually doing harm by overloading BLM tags with loads of nothing instead of important information. PLEASE don't mindlessly share what's trendy just to get on the virtue signalling bandwagon. It's unintentionally doing more harm than good.
Amplify the voices you believe are powerful. Give those in your networks exposure to new ideas and the opinions of those leading these movements.
For tangible action, donate to a cause (if you can) or write to your local MP so that the UK government is compelled to denounce US domestic policy.
A black square is empty space on your feed that could go towards helping the cause. Silence is violence.

#Bristruth29400
It‚Äôs your lucky day Bristol because you‚Äôre getting the supermarket political party pairing that nobody has asked for!
Waitrose: Conservatives. quite expensive and they include things like champagne flutes in their waitrose essentials range. Need I say more?
Sainsbury‚Äôs/Morrison‚Äôs LibDems. No one is really sure why these two supermarkets exists and yet there they are. Not really middle class enough to be tory but still somewhere M&S and Waitrose shoppers fear to tread - LibDems.
Better foods: Green Party. Do we really need an explanation? Everything is quite expensive but you can persuade yourself you‚Äôre healing the world by buying a small pack of nuts for ¬£11 from a white woman with dreadlocks.
Tesco: Labour. Bit boring but usually there for you - they boast a banging meal deal and while they are out to fleece you on most of their products, they‚Äôre more affordable than other alternatives.
Scotmid: SNP. They put the word Scot in the name of a supermarket. Need I say more?
B&M home bargains: UKIP.
Lidl/Aldi: floating voter or minor parties. These guys know what‚Äôs up
and won‚Äôt be tied down to one supermarket and are savvy enough to know to shop around. Part of this is the fact they can‚Äôt tell whether they‚Äôre in Aldi or Lidl at any given time.
Co-op: Labour and Co-operative Party. Partially the name but also because although reliable and often present - no one really knows what the co-op or the Labour co-op Party are all about.
ASDA: non voters. Who needs to vote when your favourite snacks are on rollback? Everything is usually pretty cheap and the products aren‚Äôt really anything special. As a-political as you can get.
Iceland: Brexit Party. Despite being named after a European nation this is a special reserve for those who simply detest the idea of fresh food. Food more frozen than the ice caps that you don‚Äôt believe are melting. But you don‚Äôt need to worry about that when you‚Äôre chomping on a kebab pizza do you?

text:
#Bristruth29361
RE #Bristruth29308 and anyone else in an awful position for housing next year
I was able to secure a flat very late last year and I can recommend a few things:
Find numbers for letting agents and landlords, call them directly and ask about properties. Enquiring online won‚Äôt get you anywhere quickly enough at this stage. Try contacting SU lettings and digs to ask about anything that‚Äôs come up.
Join Facebook groups- Bristol Uni housemate finder + Bristol housing, room and flat share, and even some ticket pages. If you‚Äôre finding somewhere on your own you would likely be able to find a room going.
Don‚Äôt be afraid to move further out of the city. It‚Äôs not ideal, but weigh up a bus ride with living somewhere shocking for a year if you have to. Look at places like Filton with regular buses

text:
#Bristruth29338
Is a refund reasonable?
I am definitely supportive of the cause, but the number of angry, demaning articles, headlines and facebook posts makes me feel obligated to speak out on this topic.
As an MSc student I am no stranger to the struggles of paying 9 grand a year for what is currently a bit of a shit show of a degree, but before we go throwing accusations around I think people should consider what they are asking for. The university has already frozen all non-essential spending and is doing all the can to preserve money to keep the lights on, including a freeze on hiring which leaves them in a problematic spot for coping with staff on sick leave etc. They are looking at significant debt over the next few years that will surpass the tens of millions.
On top of that, our lecturers are still working their full contracts trying to give is any semblance of the same quality of education we deserve. Many are infact working significant unpaid overtime hours to compensate for the need to completely redesign courses, exams and design next years syllabus' and teaching styles online. So when you demand a refund for your discomfort and annoyance, please consider what you're actually asking... where do you think the money is coming from? Who will suffer and why do you feel so entitled? Please respect that the staff are still working their hardest for us so the least we can do is treat them with equivalent respect and understanding.

text:
Dear Bristol,
For many of us, June is a special month, not just because of exams (although we‚Äôre as excited as you are) but because it is LGBT+ Pride month. It is a chance for people of all ages, gender identities, and backgrounds to celebrate inclusion and openness. Whoever we are, and whoever we love; pride allows us to celebrate the amazing achievements we have made in the fight for equality. It highlights the problems and injustices we still face, as well as the amazing work that people all over the world do to achieve a more equal society.
The last week has seen a horrifying event take place in the United States. One that has triggered protests all over the globe, protests whose sole aim is justice and equality. These values are at the core of pride and for that reason Bristruths wants to start pride month by highlighting the work of BME LGBT+ activists, and the work they are doing to bring justice and equality to communities all over the world.
We have a number of exciting things planned over the coming month. This will include discussing the origins of pride; what we now consider to be a celebration that was originally born from violent protest at a New York bar and club. These protests were the catalyst for a huge change of policy and attitude towards the LGBT+ community.
We hope this campaign helps to educate as well as celebrate our amazing community and we look forward to sharing those stories with you.
The Admins xxx

Dear Students
Are you currently tired and bored?, Fed up of the same dinners each week? 'Hungry' for some fresh new delicious food?
After huge interest - as promised the University of Bristol Cold Cuts society is OFFICIALLY up and running! - Bringing the finest selection of Cold Cuts to you!
Search @The University of Bristol Cold Cuts Society' on Facebook to join the group, and get regular updates on our plans for the next university year, with the first event planned in October - A tasting social - 'meat' the committee and 'meat' our esteemed members.
See you all soon, stay well and stay inside.
Spicy Chorizo.

text:
#Bristruth28727
Mario Kart DS Items Ranking
Top Tier
1)Triple Red Shells:
Best item hands down, a direct hit each time and can bring you up 3 places as well as protecting you
2)Red Shell:
Direct hit each time allows for a 95% chance of overtaking the person in front of you
every time
3)Bullet Bill:
When you‚Äôre in the depths of the last places this bad boy can get you to a high mid table position or even 3rd place, whilst empathically knocking over the people in front of you
Good tier
4)Star:
15 seconds of pure euphoria, increased pace, immortality to any item, object or opponent in your way. A shame it can‚Äôt last a bit longer
5)Spiny blue shell:
This is given to you at the bottom half of the table but can spoil the party of the leader, especially at crucial times. The ultimate ‚ÄòIf I‚Äôm going down, you‚Äôre going down with me‚Äô item
6)Triple mushrooms:
Triple boost of acceleration can be useful to get you in a good position, help you extend your lead or help you recover. Also removes the ink from your screen
7)Bob-omb:
Very good item when it lands where you want it, can leave opponents dazed for quite a while. However can sometimes go easily wrong and you end up bombing yourself
Average Tier
8)Triple green shells:
I mean only useful for protection against other items. The lack of accuracy in aim means you can rarely hit someone unless you‚Äôre right behind them
9)Golden mushroom:
You‚Äôd think unlimited acceleration would be amazing but it‚Äôs usually given when doing very bad in last place. Can help you get to mid table but runs out real quick
10)Lightning :
An okay little zinger, that removes everyone‚Äôs items in front of you and dazes them. However, it affects majority of leaders so everyone is in the same boat so little changes. Can only overtake the person in front of you really, plus the people behind you are unaffected.
11)Triple bananas:
Useful for protection but that‚Äôs it really. If planted well can get some opponents and daze them but rarely gets people as can be seen from a mile away
12)Mushroom:
Good quick boost of acceleration, can remove ink, but nothing more than that. Short and Sweet
Shite Tier
12)Banana:
Only useful is carefully well planted, otherwise useless as can be seen from a mile away and opponents can easily swerve
13)Blooper ink thing
Pretty fucking useless, yeah people can‚Äôt see their screens fully but no one slows down and it can be nullified by a mushroom or an accelerator on the track. Also affects majority of leaders so everyone is the same and little changes
14)Green shell
The absolute worst item. There‚Äôs a reason why 1st place always gets it because you can‚Äôt fucking do anything to advance yourself. Can‚Äôt protect yourself with it, no direct hit on an opponent, a 5% chance of you actually hitting an opponent
